notes.note:
This course further develops oral and written expression in a cultural context.  Students will achieve higher proficiency through reading and discussing literary and non-literary texts, grammar review, writing assignments, and viewing films.   Students will produce simple connected texts on topics which are familiar or of personal interest.  Students will also describe experiences, ideas and give reasons and explanations for opinions and plans.
This course is intended for students who have successfully completed 101-102 OR 104 (or the equivalent at other institution) OR  appropriate score in the Avant PLACE exam. 
 Students found to have more or less language experience than required for the course, will have to register at the level that is deemed appropriate.  Those wishing to retake 151 to improve on their grade must do so prior to moving into 152.

catalog.title: Intermed Fre 1st Semester
catalog.description: Continuing study of the language, includes a brief review of basic elements and the introduction and practice of more precise linguistic features. Students further their listening and speaking skills through in-class activities, as well as independent work with sound files. Also develops students' reading and writing skills through the use of literary and cultural texts.
catalog.subject: French
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: FR 101 or FR 104 or or AVANT Placement Scores of 4. For information visit: https://arts-sciences.buffalo.edu/romance-languages-literatures/language-placement-testing.html
catalog.prerequisites: FR 101 or FR 104 or or AVANT Placement Scores of 4. For information visit: https://arts-sciences.buffalo.edu/romance-languages-literatures/language-placement-testing.html

notes.note:
French 151 REC expands on the language skills mastered in FR 101 and 102 or 104. There will be a review of basic and complex grammatical and pronunciation patterns, intensive vocabulary expansion through literary and non-literary readings, and extensive conversation practice. FR 151 REC provides further in-depth practice of the language skills developed in FR 151 LEC. There will be extensive reading, writing and conversation practice.

Pre-Requisites: FR 104 or FR 102 OR  the appropriate score in the Avant PLACE exam. 
Co-Requisites: FR 151LEC

catalog.title: Intermediate French I
catalog.description: French 151 REC expands on the language skills mastered in FR 101 and 102 or 104. FR 151 REC provides further in-depth practice of the language skills developed in FR 151 LEC. There will be extensive reading, writing and conversation practice.

Pre-Requisite: FR 102 or FR 104

notes.note: 101 is for students with no experience or less than a year experience in the language (true beginners).   Students found to have more language experience than required for the course, will have to register at the level that is deemed appropriate.  Successful completion of 101 is required before registering into 102 in order to complete the 2-semester beginner's sequence.  Students who wish to retake 101 to improve on their final grade must do so prior to moving onto to 102.

catalog.title: Elem French 1st Semester
catalog.description: Language as heard and spoken; development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing; five class hours weekly plus regular drill with language recordings.

notes.note:
This is the elementary review course for most students who have studied the language for a year or two in high school and/or passed a Regents Examination in this language. 
Students must take the Avant PLACE exam in order to register for this course.
Students found to have more or less language experience than required for the course, will have to register at the level that is deemed appropriate.    
Students who have successfully completed 101 and/or 102 cannot register in 104 as this is a course duplicate.
Those wishing to retake 104 to improve on their grade must do so prior to moving to the next level, 151.

catalog.title: Transitional Elem French
catalog.description: One-semester review course designed for students who have taken the Regents exams, but who are not yet able to go into the second year of language study. Involves development of all four language skills (listening, speaking, reading, and, to some extent, writing), emphasizing the grammatical structures and vocabulary fundamental to simple, everyday conversation.
catalog.subject: French

notes.note: This is a continuation course in the 151-152 sequence.  Students must have successfully completed 151 (at UB or the equivalent at another institution)  before registering into 152 or with the appropriate level in the Avant PLACE exam..   Those wishing to retake 152 to improve on their grade must do so prior to moving into the 200-level.

notes.note: FR 484/FR 525 KRE2 Intermediate Kreyol - an intermediate course which is based on a variety of sources, including ISTWA AYITI, CHITA PA BAY, and various other sources gleaned from social media.  The course is intended to be very practical and fundamental in understanding native speakers. This course will focus on speaking, listening, reading, writing/ and culture.  There is emphasis on communication with grammatical accuracy.  Learning time will be devoted primarily to developing spoken, written and oral communication skills through interaction with the instructor and other native speakers.

notes.note:
Spring 2022:  Introduction to Kreyol

FR 483 is an introductory course designed for students who have had no prior instruction in Haitian Creole. You will develop skills in reading, speaking, listening and writing Haitian Creole. Emphasis is placed on listening, comprehension, pronunciation, basic vocabulary, and grammar structures necessary for developing oral proficiency skills. Classroom work is extended and enhanced by homework and other activities.

notes.note:
Spring 2022:  Please be advised that a portion of this class may be switched from in person to remote-synchronous.  Please check back prior to the start of classes for updates.


Introduces students to major currents of French literature and thought in selected readings from the Middle Ages, Renaissance, Classical period, and Enlightenment. The study of epic (La Chanson de Roland), romance (Yvain ou le chevalier au lion), autobiographical writing (Montaigne's Essais), classical tragedy and comedy (Racine and Molière), the novel (La Princesse de Clèves and Candide), philosophical writing (selections from Descartes, Pascal, and Rousseau), and poetry (selections from Charles d'Orléans, Villon, Du Bellay, and Ronsard) emphasizes both literary and philosophical traditions, as well as textual interpretation.

 Pre-Requisite: FR 211 or FR 212 or FR 213 or FR 271 or FR 270, or  the appropriate AVANT placement test score. Taught in French.

catalog.title: Survey of French Lit I
catalog.description: Introduces students to major currents of French literature and thought in selected readings from the Middle Ages, Renaissance, Classical period, and Enlightenment. The study of epic (La Chanson de Roland), romance (Yvain ou le chevalier au lion), autobiographical writing (Montaigne's Essais), classical tragedy and comedy (Racine and Molière), the novel (La Princesse de Clèves and Candide), philosophical writing (selections from Descartes, Pascal, and Rousseau), and poetry (selections from Charles d'Orléans, Villon, Du Bellay, and Ronsard) emphasizes both literary and philosophical traditions, as well as textual interpretation.

notes.note:
This course is part of the FR 211-FR 213 three-course module: these three courses can be taken in any order, they do not need to be taken sequentially.  Course goals are achieved through reading, discussion, and written analysis of texts like plays, films, music, interviews, and performances from the French-speaking world, as well as through debates and staged readings.
"Prerequisites:  FR 152; or equivalent, as determined by RLL faculty advisor or placement based on Avant PLACE exam.  Students enrolled in or having successfully completed at least two upper-level (FR 300/400) courses cannot take these courses.

catalog.title: Languages/Texts/Contexts III
catalog.description: This course is part of the FR 211-FR 213 three-course module: these three courses can be taken in any order, they do not need to be taken sequentially. This particular course enriches specific intermediate-level skills for more advanced use: it focuses on investigating, persuading, and argumentation. It allows students to practice the forms of discourse necessary for defense and justification at the same time that it encourages critical thinking by scrutinizing and analyzing modes of persuasion intended to manipulate and evade. Course goals are achieved through the study of texts like essays, novels, films, and performances coming from various social contexts of French-language cultures as well as through the honing of written and verbal skills of inquiry, research analysis and synthesis necessary for exploring texts and their contexts.
catalog.subject: French
catalog.long_title: Languages, Texts, and Contexts of the French-Speaking World III
catalog.requisites_description: Prerequisites: FR 152 or permission of the department.
catalog.prerequisites: FR 152 or permission of the department
